DataElement.preferredName: Blood Physical Contact Assay Type BloodContactAssayType
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A liquid tissue; its major function is to transport oxygen throughout the body. It also supplies the tissues with nutrients, removes waste products, and contains various components of the immune system defending the body against infection. Several hormones also travel in the blood.:The act of touching physically; the physical coming together of two or more things._The determination of the amount of a particular constituent of a mixture or of the biological or pharmacological potency of a drug.:Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities._The list of values for blood contact assay types.

It also supplies the tissues with nutrients, removes waste products, and contains various components of the immune system defending the body against infection. ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The list of values for blood contact assay types.

Concepts.definition: The process of clot formation. (from On-line Medical Dictionary)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The complement system consists of more than 30 proteins engaged in host defense. It provides both an independent immune system capable of attacking microbes as well as other foreign material and an adjunct to the antibody system. Once activated, the complement system fires in a cascade-like fashion in which one component activates the next. Both swift and powerful, millions of complement components can deposit on an invading microbe within only a few minutes. Such a potent system requires strict regulation to avoid host injury. Membrane cofactor protein (MCP) is one critical regulator aimed at controlling inadvertent complement activation on host cells and nearly every cell examined expresses MCP on its cell membrane.

Concepts.definition: Any physiologic process in which a protease directs the cleavage of complement components C4, C2, or factor B which then form the C3 and C5 convertases for the classical and lectin pathways, respectively. This process is involved in direct lysis of target cells, immune adherence and phagocytosis of pathogens, and recruitment and activation of immunocompetent cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Disruption of the integrity of the erythrocyte membrane causing release of hemoglobin.

Concepts.definition: Disruption of the integrity of the erythrocyte membrane causing release of hemoglobin.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Dissolved proteins of blood plasma.  These mainly consist of albumins and globulins and include antibodies and blood-clotting proteins.:Involves temporary, non-covalent binding of two or more molecules as a result of intermolecular physical forces and often involves spatial complementarity between the interacting objects.

Concepts.definition: Dissolved proteins of blood plasma.  These mainly consist of albumins and globulins and include antibodies and blood-clotting proteins.
Involves temporary, non-covalent binding of two or more molecules as a result of intermolecular physical forces and often involves spatial complementarity between the interacting objects.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The accumulation and adherence of platelets to form a clot or thrombus. When injury or bleeding occurs, platelets clump together at the site of injury; they expand and adhere to the injured area, thereby acting as a plug to reduce the bleeding. Platelet dysfunction can result in blood clotting and bleeding disorders.

Concepts.definition: Any cell adhesion process that involves the association of platelets via adhesion molecules.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: An action taken in pursuit of an objective; the state of being active.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
